Another interesting type of node split might be a parallel split rather t=
han the serial split you described.  So you would basically duplicate the n=
ode and its incoming and outgoing connections.  That might be sort of like =
gene duplication that can then lead to a divergence.  However, the new weig=
hts would perhaps need to be calibrated since it would double the power of =
the prior single-node output.

ken

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Colin Gree=
n <colin.green1@...> wrote:
>
> The standard NEAT approach for adding nodes=
 is to split a connection, e.g.
> 
> 1------>2
> Split connection to give
>=
 1---->3---->2
> 
> I was wondering if splitting nodes would have additiona=
l worth. E.g.
> 
> (1,2,3) ---> 4 ---> (5,6,7)
> Split 4 to give:
> (1,2,3)=
 ---> 4 ---> 8 ---> (5,6,7)
> 
> So 4 became 4 and 8 with a connection betw=
een them. One notable change
> this allows is for lots of connections comin=
g into an output node to
> be split away into a hidden node adjacent to the=
 output.
> 
> (1,2,3) ---> out
> Split output node:
> (1,2,3) ---> 4 ---> o=
ut
> 
> Same for an input:
> in ----> (1,2,3)
> Split input node:
> in --->=
 4 ---> (1,2,3)
> 
> 
> Any thoughts?
> 
> Colin.
>
